In the context of signal processing, consider a system where a signal \( x(t) \) passes through a linear time-invariant (LTI) system characterized by its impulse response \( h(t) \). If \( x(t) \) is transformed by a Fourier Transform and then processed by the LTI system, will \( y(t) \) at any later time \( t \) necessarily reflect only alterations due to \( H(\omega) \) applied to \( X(\omega) \)?
Question Type: from cause to effect without intervention
Explanation: Since the system is LTI and the transformation is linear, the resulting \( y(t) \) only depends on the input \( X(\omega) \) and the system's response \( H(\omega) \). The transformation \( \mathcal{F} \) linearly represents \( x(t) \) in the frequency domain where it is directly modified by \( H(\omega) \).
